issues.text: Whether the certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 134(1)(c) satisfies the constitutional requirements for appeal to the Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the High Court granted the certificate of fitness under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution not on any difficult question of law or procedure which it thought required to be settled by this Court, but on a question which is essentially one of fact, namely, whether there was sufficient evidence of the guilt of the accused.

issues.text: Whether there are grounds justifying the grant of special leave to appeal under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: satisfy ourselves whether there are such grounds as would justify this Court in granting special leave to appeal to this Court

issues.text: Whether it is settled law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction without corroboration

anchor.surface_text: we have, therefore, to examine the legal position whether it is settled law that a dying declaration by itself can, in no circumstances, be the basis of a conviction.

issues.text: Whether the dying declarations made by Baboolal are reliable and sufficient to sustain the conviction

issues.text: Whether there are extenuating circumstances justifying a sentence lesser than death for the murder under s.302 IPC

anchor.surface_text: under s. 302, Indian Penal Code, for the pre-meditated murder of Baboolal on the night of February 12, 1956

arguments.claim: Certificate of fitness under Art. 134(1)(c) is justified due to insufficient evidence against the accused and error in judgment regarding absconding being linked to a liquor case.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground for the grant of the certificate may be reproduced in the words of the High Court itself The main ground is that there is number enough evidence against the accused and that there is an error in our judg- ment in holding that there was numberevidence to show that Khushal whose absconding has been held to companyroborate the dying declaration, was involved in a liquor case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he High Court very reluctant- ly gave the benefit of the doubt to Tukaram and allowed his appeal. The High Court also agreed with the trial Judge in a

arguments.court_reasoning: Certificate granted on question of fact (sufficiency of evidence), not substantial question of law as required by Art. 134(1)(c); High Court exceeds power per precedents like Haripada Dey.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in relying on absconding as corroboration because appellant was absconding due to a liquor case.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of the argument neither side drew our attention to the documents which were in the record number was any point made of it, though we questioned why the absconding should number be taken into companysideration. Now it seems that there are one or two defence exhibits in which it has been shown that Khushal was number found in his house when he was wanted in a liquor case after a search on 5th February, 1956.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ector of police and the third, by the magistrate, first class, between 9-25 and 11-35 p. m. As regards authenticity of the record of those three state

arguments.court_reasoning: Defence explanation rejected; records examined, no good reason to differ from HC; absconding consistent with guilt but not necessary.

arguments.claim: Conviction cannot be based solely on dying declarations without corroboration, as per Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of MP; dying declarations are unsafe without further corroboration due to no oath/cross-exam.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, a good deal of argument was addressed to us, to the effect that the ruling of this Court lays down a sound proposition of law which should have been followed by the High Court, and that the alleged fact of the accused absconding and keeping out of the way of the police companyld number be used as companyroboration of the dying declaration. The decision of this Court in Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh  1 , companytains the following observations, at p. 423, which have been very strongly relied upon, on behalf of the appellant, as having a great bearing upon the value to be placed upon the dying declarations It is settled law that it is number safe to companyvict an accused person merely on the evidence furnished by a dying declara- tion without further companyroboration because such a statement is number made on oath and is number subject to cross-examination

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the true sense. The Court must, of companyrse, be fully company- vinced of the truth of the statement and, naturally, it companyld number be fully com

arguments.court_reasoning: Observations in Ram Nath are obiter dicta; not settled law; dying decl can be sole basis if reliable after scrutiny.

arguments.claim: Oral testimony of eye-witnesses (Inayatullah, Sadashiv, etc.) is partisan and unreliable, cannot be used even for corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court examined, in meticulous details, the evidence of the eye-wit- nesses Inayatullah, P.W. 1, and Sadashiv, P.W. 3, and agreed with the trial Judge in his estimate of their testimony that those witnesses being partisan, their evidence companyld number be relied upon, to base a companyviction. The High Court went further and came to the. companyclusion that their evidence being suspect, companyld number be used even as companyroboration, if companyroboration was needed of the three dying declarations made by Baboolal, as aforesaid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e companysiderations, it has got to be held -that the certificate of fitness granted by the High Court does number satisfy the requirements of Art. 13

arguments.court_reasoning: SC proceeds on assumption that HC is right in rejecting oral testimony as partisan.

arguments.claim: Dying declarations are corroborated by appellant's absconding and suspicious arrest, sufficient for conviction.

anchor.surface_text: They upheld the companyviction and sentence of the appellant on the ground that the dying declarations were companyroborated by the fact that the appel- lant had been absconding and keeping out of the way of the police, and had been arrested under very suspicious circum- stances.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: victions on dying declarations alone had been rested if the Court was satisfied that the dying declaration was true and, therefore, companyld be acte

arguments.court_reasoning: Absconding provides some corroboration but not necessary; dying decl reliable on own.

arguments.claim: Dying declaration is admissible and reliable under s.32(1) Evidence Act as exception to hearsay; solemn occasion substitutes cross-exam; no absolute need for corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature in its wisdom has enacted in s. 32 1  of the Evidence Act that When the statement is made by a person as to the cause of his death, or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death, in cases in which the cause of that persons death companyes into question, such a statement written or verbal made by a person who is dead  omitting the unnecessary words  is itself a relevant fact. This provision has been made by the Legislature, advisedly, as a matter of sheer necessity -by way of an exception to the general rule that hearsay is numberevidence and that evidence, which has number been tested by cross-exami- nation, is number admissible.

arguments.claim: No absolute rule requiring corroboration for dying declaration unlike accomplice evidence under s.133/114(b) Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Though under s. 133 of the Evidence Act, it is number illegal to companyvict a person on the uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice, illustration  b  to s. 114 of the Act lays down as a rule of prudence based on experience, that an accom- plice is unworthy of credit unless his evidence is companyrobo- rated in material particulars and this has number been accepted as a rule of law. The same cannot be said of a dying decla- ration because a dying declaration may number, unlike a companyfes- sion, or the testimony of an approver, companye from a tainted source.

arguments.claim: Dying declarations here are reliable: consistent naming of appellant, earliest opportunity, no tutoring, fit state of mind, proper recording.

anchor.surface_text: The most remarkable fact which emerges from an examination of the three successive dying declarations made in the companyrse of about two hours, by the deceased, is that he company sistently named the appellant and Tukaram as the persons who had assaulted him with sword and spear. The injuries found on his person, namely, the punctured wounds and the incised wounds on different parts, of his body, are entirely company- sistent with his statement that he was attacked by a number of persons with cutting and piercing weapons.

arguments.claim: Absconding of appellant provides corroboration consistent with guilt.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court took the view that the circumstance of the appellants companyduct in companycealing himself and evading the police for a number of days was companysistent with the prosecution case that he was companycerned in the crime which was the subject-matter of the charge against him.

arguments.claim: Trial court convicted under s.302 or alternatively 302/34 based on dying declarations and oral evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge acquitted two of them and companyvict- ed the remaining two the appellant and Tukaram-under s. 302. Indian Penal Code, or in the alternative, tinder s. 302, read with s. 34, Indian Penal Code. He sentenced the appel- lant to death because in his opinion, he had caused Baboolals death intentionally, and there were numberextenuat- ing circumstances.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: h, against the two accused per- sons who had been acquitted by the learned trial Judge, and the revisional application for enhancement of sentence pas

arguments.claim: No extenuating circumstances; deliberate cold-blooded murder warrants death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question that remains to be companysidered is whether there are any extenuating circumstances in favour of the accused justify- ing the lesser of the two sentences prescribed by law. In our opinion, there are numbere. It was a case of a deliberate companyd-blooded murder.

holdings.text: The certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 134(1)(c) does not satisfy the constitutional requirements as it was granted on a question of fact (sufficiency of evidence), not a substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these considerations, it has got to be held -that the certificate of fitness granted by the High Court does number satisfy the requirements of Art. 134 1  c  of the Con- stitution. The appeal on such a certificate has, therefore,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court granted certificate on sufficiency of evidence (fact), not law, exceeding power per precedents like Haripada Dey; appeal dismissed in limine.

holdings.text: There are no grounds justifying special leave to appeal under Article 136 warranting interference with the conviction.

anchor.surface_text: but we have to satisfy ourselves whether there are such grounds as would justify this Court in granting special leave to appeal to this Court, if the appellant had approached this Court in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines merits despite invalid certificate and finds no error justifying interference.

holdings.text: It is not settled law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction without corroboration; it can if reliable after scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act and of the decided cases in the different High Courts in India and in this Court, we have come to the conclusion, in agreement with the opinion of the Full Bench of the Madras High Court, aforesaid,  1  that it cannot be laid down as an absolute rule of law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction unless it is corroborated

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes obiter in Ram Nath; s.32(1) Evidence Act gives special sanctity; unlike accomplice evidence under s.133/114(b); surveys High Court precedents.

holdings.text: The dying declarations of Baboolal are reliable and sufficient to sustain the conviction under s.302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The most remarkable fact which emerges from an examination of the three successive dying declarations made in the course of about two hours, by the deceased, is that he consistently named the appellant and Tukaram as the persons who had assaulted him with sword and spear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent across three declarations in quick succession; earliest opportunity; fit state of mind certified; no tutoring; consistent with injuries; proper recording.

holdings.text: Appellant's absconding and evasion of police is consistent with guilt and provides corroboration, though not necessary.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court took the view that the circumstance of the appellants conduct in concealing himself and evading the police for a number of days was consistent with the prosecution case that he was concerned in the crime which was the subject-matter of the charge against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects defense liquor case explanation after record check; suspicious arrest; but dying declarations reliable independently.

holdings.text: There are no extenuating circumstances justifying a lesser sentence than death for the deliberate cold-blooded murder under s.302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question that remains to be considered is whether there are any extenuating circumstances in favour of the accused justifying the lesser of the two sentences prescribed by law. In our opinion, there are none. It was a case of a deliberate cold-blooded murder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-meditated murder of rival faction associate; no mitigating factors.

holdings.text: Oral eye-witness testimony is partisan and unreliable, cannot form basis of conviction or even corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court examined, in meticulous details, the evidence of the eye-witnesses Inayatullah, P.W. 1, and Sadashiv, P.W. 3, and agreed with the trial Judge in his estimate of their testimony that those witnesses being partisan, their evidence could not be relied upon, to base a conviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court proceeds on High Court's assessment of partisanship and failure to rescue victim.

holdings.text: Observations in Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of MP requiring corroboration for dying declarations are obiter dicta.

anchor.surface_text: It is, thus clear that the observations quoted above, of this Court, are in the nature of obiter dicta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court in Ram Nath examined facts closely and found declarations unreliable; dictum not ratio.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act and of the decided cases in the different High Courts in India and in this Court, we have come to the conclusion, in agreement with the opinion of the Full Bench of the Madras High Court, aforesaid,  1  that it cannot be laid down as an absolute rule of law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction unless it is corroborated
For the reasons given above, we uphold the judgment and order of the High Court convicting the appellant of murder and sentencing him to death.

anchor.surface_text: The most remarkable fact which emerges from an examination of the three successive dying declarations made in the course of about two hours, by the deceased, is that he consistently named the appellant and Tukaram as the persons who had assaulted him with sword and spear.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question that remains to be considered is whether there are any extenuating circumstances in favour of the accused justifying the lesser of the two sentences prescribed by law. In our opinion, there are none. It was a case of a deliberate cold-blooded murder.
For the reasons given above, we uphold the judgment and order of the High Court convicting the appellant of murder and sentencing him to death.
